resources.string: Explore historical facts about your environment.

string-array.name: UK_array
string-array.item: The United Kingdom is home to the town with the longest name in the world, Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch, fortunately the town is known also as Llanfairpwllgwyngyll or simply Llanfair PG.
The UK is home to some of the world\'s most famous writers, including William Shakespeare, Jane Austen, Charles Dickens, and J.K. Rowling.
The shortest war in history was between Zanzibar and Great Britain, and it lasted only 38 minutes.
The UK was the first country to build a subway system, the London Underground, which opened in 1863.
The UK is the only country in the world with two official national anthems: "God Save the Queen" and "Flower of Scotland."
The world\'s first postage stamp, the Penny Black, was issued in the UK in 1840.
The UK is the birthplace of many popular sports, including soccer, rugby, cricket, and tennis.

string-array.name: Nigeria_array
string-array.item: The Igbo people of southeastern Nigeria declared an independent state called Biafra in 1967, which led to a civil war that lasted until 1970.
Nigeria has produced many internationally renowned writers, including Chinua Achebe, Wole Soyinka, and Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
The Nok civilization, which flourished in present-day Nigeria from around 1000 BC to 300 AD, produced some of the earliest known sculptures in Sub-Saharan Africa.
The Sokoto Caliphate, a Muslim state in northern Nigeria, was one of the largest empires in Africa in the 19th century.
Nigeria is home to the oldest known boat in Africa, the Dufuna Canoe, which was discovered in Yobe State and dates back to around 8500 BC.

The ancient city of Ife, in southwestern Nigeria, is the site of a major archaeological discovery: a terracotta head believed to be from the 12th century. The head, which depicts a woman with elaborate hair and jewelry, is considered a masterpiece of African art.
The National Arts Theatre in Lagos, which was completed in 1976, is the largest arts and culture complex in Africa.
The Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport in Abuja is named after Nnamdi Azikiwe, a prominent Nigerian nationalist who was the country\'s first president.
The Nigerian Stock Exchange, which was founded in 1960, is the third-largest stock exchange in Africa, after the Johannesburg Stock Exchange and the Egyptian Exchange.
The Nigerian flag, which was designed in 1959 by Michael Taiwo Akinkunmi, features two green stripes representing Nigeria\'s agriculture, and a white stripe representing peace.
The Nigerian Civil War, which lasted from 1967 to 1970, resulted in the deaths of over a million people and had a profound impact on Nigerian society and politics.
